abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Road Sector Development
            Project for Ghana were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the Bank's preparedness criteria requires
            that first year works should be fully designed and ready for
            contracting as soon as the project becomes effective. Major
            differences between expected and actual costs may often
            result in the face of poorly designed projects. A detailed
            monitoring and evaluation system is critical for effective
            supervision and to adapt the project design to address
            specific needs during implementation. Focus should not only
            be limited to capturing the 'output' indicators
            but also the 'outcome' indicators. A first time
            preparation and implementation of safeguards instruments
            requires close supervision and consistent support of the
            client. Acquiring at detailed design stage, the Executive
            Instrument, which in Ghana, is the document that authorizes
            land acquisition, is key to a timely preparation and
            implementation of a Resettlement Action Plan (RAP).

repnme.cdata!: Ghana - Road Sector Development Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Ghana
            Roads Sector Development Program Project is to achieve
            sustainable improvements in the supply, and performance of
            roads transport services, in a regionally equitable manner.
            The project components are: 1) routine maintenance,
            consisting of patching potholes; lightning, vegetative
            propagation along roadsides, and drainage maintenance; 2)
            periodic maintenance, minor rehabilitation, and upgrading of
            trunk roads, and urban roads consist of spot improvements,
            road resurfacing and resealing, and slope repairs. Feeder
            roads include re-graveling, and drainage repairs; 3) major
            rehabilitation, reconstruction, and upgrading, will include
            reconstruction, or rehabilitation of paved/unpaved roads,
            resealing, and upgrading from gravel to bitumen, or from
            bituminous-treated surfaces, to asphalt/concrete surfaces.
            Repair, and construction of bridges will also be included,
            as well as for trunk roads, feeder roads, and urban roads
            segments; 4) traffic management, and safety, to develop
            comprehensive programs on safety strategies, by
            strengthening the National Road Safety Council, and the
            Driver and Vehicle Licensing Authority, through reforms,
            computerization, and training of traffic officials; 5)
            institutional strengthening, particularly as it regards
            environmental policies vs. road works, and directives for
            social, and gender equity, through the provision of studies,
            training, and technical assistance; and, 6) project
            management, coordination, monitoring, and reporting on the
            road development program.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Road Sector Development Program
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Sector Development Program
            (RSDP) Project involves the rehabilitation of roads
            following existing alignments, thus, it is expected that
            environmental impacts will be minimal. Nevertheless, this
            environmental assessment reviews the legal, and
            administrative framework in Ghana, and the alternatives
            examined for improvement of existing roads. It specifies
            that clearing around the right-of-way, or for borrow pits
            may threaten ecosystems, such as forests, wetlands and
            wildlife refuges; construction works may lead to
            sedimentation, and pollution of streams, and water bodies,
            resulting from the operation of heavy machinery; potential
            erosion, and inadequate drainage would increase water
            pollution levels; and, air, and noise pollution, as a result
            of construction, and increased traffic, may affect roadside
            communities, in terms of health and safety problems.
            Mitigation include: 1) installation of culverts to prevent
            water logging, and an immediate vegetative propagation, will
            minimize soil erosion, and sedimentation; 2) drainage
            discharges will be appropriately located to control, and
            manage solid wastes, fuel and oil spills, and sewage to
            prevent water pollution; 3) likewise, groundwater leakage,
            and pollution of water resources will be adequately
            discharged, in accordance with sanitary measures; 4) a
            buffer zone will be maintained to protect, and preserve
            local flora and fauna; and, 5) spraying, and surface covers
            will minimize dust pollution; vehicle maintenance and
            regular working schedules would reduce noise disturbances;
            and, traffic safety include the installation of traffic
            signs, and provision of alternate route diversions.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Road Sector Development Program
            Project : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The resettlement action plan (RAP) for
            the Road Sector Development Program Project in Ghana,
            reviews the land acquisition and compensation laws, which
            provides entitlement to compensation for affected property
            by public projects, as well as the possibility to seek
            redress through other avenues for people not satisfied with
            compensation. The RAP recommends the preparation of a social
            assessment, to include the demographic, and socioeconomic
            profile of affected populations, and an assessment of
            potential impacts on cultural, social and economic aspects,
            suggesting mitigation plans, and the application of a
            framework for compensation and resettlement as follows. The
            RAP stipulates institutional arrangements among the
            country's agencies and units, to align and identify the
            properties affected, followed by valuation of properties,
            presented at public forum, and in consultation with affected
            people. Monitoring, and assessment should follow, to adjust
            valuation as necessary, based on database information to
            control timing, and compensation issues. Authorization of
            payment will be made prior to resettlement and demolition,
            and, assistance will be provided to cover resettlement
            costs. Grievance mechanisms will be established to receive,
            and resolve possible complaints, and an independent
            evaluation of impacts will be coordinated.
